author: .shimond
content: Why have the time between withdrawals and the merge be so long? As far as I understand, withdrawals are spec'd and pretty much ready to go (not nearly as complex as the merge), and stability concerns will (hopefully) be put to bed within a few days

author: sky.cactus
content: There is a spec proposal for withdraws, but I don't believe any code has been written yet and I think the spec is still not finalized.

author: .shimond
content: And you think 6-8 months is a reasonable estimate for development, testing, and deployment given that it will be top priority post merge?

author: sky.cactus
content: I think 6-8 months is on the optimistic side personally, just because as Ethereum continues to grow coordination becomes harder.  Also, because we no longer have the Ice Age as of The Merge, I suspect we are going to get worse at regularly releasing.

author: .shimond
content: Thanks for the response. Is there an incentive structure for client teams to continue coordinating effectively post merge?

author: sky.cactus
content: Nothing external, only an internal desire to make things better.

author: potuz
content: I'm on the other side here. I can't evaluate how hard it will be to implement a new type of operation on the execution size. But one would guess that the changes are more important in the consensus side and they are fairly simple to implement. We didn't do so already cause there was internal pushback to not merge code in develop, but as soon as the merge release is out we can continue

author: potuz
content: But I agree with something: this requires coordination. Specifically I foresee still arguments in specifying the API endpoints and the JSON schema for their messages. Also independent tooling like the deposit-cli needs to be built, and even probably sites that broadcast the BLS to execution address change message
